<summary>

• The Internet's domain name system (DNS) is crucial for commerce, vital services, and international communication, relying on a set of functions and a system of "root servers" for coordination.
• The U.S. government historically supported DNS implementation, but transitioned responsibility to the private sector in 1998 through the creation of ICANN, with the goal of increasing competition, stability, security, and community representation.
• ICANN has made progress in promoting competition, such as reducing the cost of securing domain names and expanding the pool of available domain names, but has faced challenges in other areas like security and community representation.
• The White Paper identified the stability and security of the Internet as the top priority of the transition, with ICANN and the Department tasked to develop operational requirements and security policies for root server enhancements.
• Despite some progress, ICANN's efforts to enhance stability, security, and formalize relationships with other entities involved in running the DNS have been slower than expected, with few agreements signed as of May 2002.
• The Department of Commerce, responsible for general oversight of the transition, has not provided detailed public assessments or status reports on ICANN's progress, citing sensitivity to international concerns.

</summary>

<summary>
• In 1998, the VA and DOD began developing a joint capability to share patient health information for active duty military personnel and veterans, starting with the GCPR project. However, the lack of a lead entity, clear mission, and detailed planning made it difficult to manage the project.
• In response to recommendations, the GCPR project was revised and renamed the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program in 2001, with VA designated as the lead entity. The FHIE program was successfully implemented, enabling the one-way transfer of data from DOD's health information system to a separate database accessible by VA clinicians. However, not all DOD medical information is captured in CHCS, and the departments are working on a longer-term, two-way exchange of health information through the HealthePeople (Federal) initiative.
</summary>

<summary>

* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820.
* The General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for the division of tribal lands into individual allotments, and the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands.
* Many allotments are now jointly owned in common by hundreds or thousands of individual Indians, each with an undivided interest in the whole parcel.
* The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for accounting for the revenue generated by each interest, investing trust funds, and providing other trust services.
* In 2003, the Secretary of the Interior initiated an effort to develop a comprehensive plan for improving Indian trust management, resulting in the Comprehensive Trust Management Plan.
* In response to recommendations from Electronic Data Systems, the Secretary reorganized the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and the Office of Special Trustee (OST) in 2003.
* OST's budget and staff have grown significantly since 1997, mainly due to OST's efforts to implement reforms and its growing responsibility for trust fund management.
* OST is responsible for implementing trust reforms associated with the trust funds accounting system and the overall integration of various trust reform automated systems.
* OST has not prepared a timetable for completing its remaining trust reform activities or identified a date for its termination under the 1994 Act.
</summary>

<summary>
• Ginnie Mae, a government-owned corporation, guarantees timely payment of principal and interest on mortgage-backed securities (MBS) backed by government-insured loans.
• Ginnie Mae's market share of new MBS issuance has declined from 42% in 1985 to 7% in 2004, while the outstanding volume of FHA and VA loans has also fallen.
• Ginnie Mae's share of the total MBS market has declined due to the growth of the conventional market and the increasing number of conventional mortgage originations and securitizations.
• Ginnie Mae's market share of outstanding MBS has also declined from 54% in 1985 to 10% in 2004, due to the increase in borrowers refinancing out of FHA and VA loan programs into conventional loans.
• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined by approximately 26% from $612 billion in 2000 to $453 billion in 2004.
• Ginnie Mae's share of the government-backed mortgage market has been fairly constant, but a decline in the proportion of high-quality mortgages in Ginnie Mae's MBS could raise costs for borrowers.
• Ginnie Mae's revenues exceed its expenses, reducing the federal budget deficit, but a decline in income could affect its contribution to reducing the deficit.
• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined in recent years due to the outstanding volume of FHA and VA loans falling as growing numbers of borrowers refinance in the conventional market.
• Ginnie Mae's securities have at least adequate liquidity, but reduced liquidity could have some effect on the costs to borrowers of government-backed loans.
</summary>

<summary>

* The IRS's call center network, which includes 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites, was consolidated into a single call center in 1999 to enable more efficient call routing.
* The Operations Center, which controls the network, is responsible for forecasting call demand, planning call routing, developing staffing requirements, and monitoring network traffic.
* The IRS's approach to setting staffing levels is inconsistent with federal guidance and industry practices, and without a long-term service goal, IRS lacks meaningful targets for managing call center performance.
* The IRS recognizes the need to establish long-term goals and is considering adopting measures used by other organizations, such as measuring the percentage of callers who reach IRS within 30 seconds.
* The six call sites visited faced challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives, with difficulties including job characteristics, limited time for hiring, and a lack of adequate resources.
* IRS is in the early stages of developing a national recruiting strategy and is determining where it should target its recruiting efforts to help ensure that it hires sufficient numbers of qualified customer service representatives.
* IRS must train thousands of customer service representatives each year in a broad range of topics, but after initial training, representatives generally do not receive subsequent refresher training, which affects their ability to stay proficient.
* IRS has not established a system for assessing the refresher training needs of individual representatives, which leads to inefficient use of training resources and prevents representatives from receiving targeted training.
* IRS is not actively monitoring attrition and determining what steps, if any, are needed to address it, which is a concern given the substantial investment in recruiting and training its customer service representatives.
* IRS faces challenges in effectively scheduling staff due to inaccurate demand forecasting and a complicated staff scheduling process, and is adapting an automated system to help improve forecasting and scheduling.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) has agreed to reverse 96% of the $615 million of illegal and improper closed account adjustments identified in a prior report. However, due to DOD's accounting accuracy problems, the reversal of these transactions has brought to light additional accounting issues that require detailed reviews.

• Of the remaining $23 million of adjustments, DOD has provided additional documentation indicating that $8 million were proper, but $15 million are still considered unnecessary or unsupported by DOD. The reversal of these adjustments has also identified accounting errors in 77% of the $592 million of reversed transactions, which will take an estimated 21,000 hours to correct.

• DOD has taken actions to eliminate illegal or improper adjustments involving closed account records, resulting in an 80% reduction of closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002. However, there are still thousands of older contracts in MOCAS with closed accounts that will need to be monitored closely to ensure that illegal or improper adjustments do not occur.

• The options for Congress to consider include taking no legislative action and allowing DOD to adjust closed account records when appropriate to correct accounting errors, or amending the account closing law to prohibit any adjustments to an appropriation account after it is closed. The latter option would eliminate adjustments to closed accounts but would also make it impossible to correct known errors in accounting records once the account is closed.

• The report recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to ensure that DFAS Columbus completes its review and correction of the remaining fiscal year 2000 illegal and otherwise improper adjustments, reverse closed account adjustments made during fiscal year 2001, determine the entries necessary to correct the accounting for reversed fiscal year 2001 transactions, and continue with DFAS’s top-level management attention and monitoring of the program for future adjustments to closed appropriation accounts.
</summary>

<summary>

* The electricity industry is composed of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* The industry has begun to integrate new technologies and IT systems to modernize the grid and improve reliability, efficiency, and support for renewable energy.
* The federal government and state governments have authority for overseeing the electricity industry, including regulating rates, transmission, and distribution.
* Threats to the electricity industry can come from various sources, including natural disasters, defective equipment, careless employees, and cyber attacks.
* NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy have taken steps to help secure the electricity grid.
* Challenges in securing the electricity grid include monitoring implementation of cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, and effectively sharing cybersecurity information.
</summary>

• The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) uses the Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to measure the quality of closed audits against nine IRS audit standards.
• Each standard includes additional key elements describing specific components of a quality audit, and workpapers provide the principal support for the examiner's report.
• The EQMS measures whether consideration was given to the large, unusual, or questionable items in both the precontact stage and during the course of the examination.
• It also measures whether the steps taken verified that the proper amount of income was reported, and whether consideration was given to filing and examination potential of all returns required by the taxpayer.
• The EQMS measures whether the issues examined were completed to the extent necessary to provide sufficient information to determine substantially correct tax.
• It also measures whether the conclusions reached were based on a correct application of tax law, and whether applicable penalties were considered and applied correctly.
• The EQMS measures the documentation of the examination's audit trail and techniques used, and the presentation of the audit findings in terms of content, format, and accuracy.
• IRS uses the key element pass rate as one measure of audit quality, which computes the percentage of audits demonstrating the characteristics defined by the key element.
• According to IRS, the key element pass rate is the most sensitive measurement and is useful when describing how an audit is flawed, establishing a baseline for improvement, and identifying systemic changes.
• The Office of Compliance Specialization, within the IRS’ Examination Division, has responsibility for Quality Measurement Staff operations and the EQMS.

<summary>

* The two approaches for reorganizing or terminating a large financial company are bankruptcy and special legal/regulatory resolution regimes.
* Bankruptcy is a federal court procedure aimed at helping individuals/businesses eliminate or restructure debts, with an automatic stay on most lawsuits/collection activities.
* Equitable treatment of creditors means similar claims are classified and treated similarly, with secured creditors receiving similar treatment for secured claims.
* Business debtors may seek liquidation under Chapter 7 or reorganization under Chapter 11, with proceedings being voluntary or involuntary.
* A Chapter 7 proceeding involves a trustee taking over the assets, reducing them to cash, and distributing them to creditors.
* A reorganization proceeding under Chapter 11 allows debtors to continue operations while satisfying creditor claims.
* The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference, AOUSC, the Federal Judicial Center, and the U.S. Trustee/Bankruptcy Administrator Programs.
* A preference action can be asserted for payments made to an insider within a year prior to bankruptcy, and large financial companies generally file for bankruptcy under Chapter 11.
</summary>

<summary>

• The federal government faces mission-critical skills gaps, particularly in areas like cybersecurity and acquisitions, which hinder its ability to efficiently serve the public. These gaps may be due to insufficient staffing or lack of appropriate skills among employees.

• Current budget constraints, changing nature of federal work, and a potential wave of retirements threaten to exacerbate these skills gaps. A significant portion of the federal workforce is eligible to retire by 2020, which could lead to gaps in institutional knowledge and leadership.

• Numerous challenges exist in addressing talent needs, including an outdated classification system, a cumbersome hiring process, an outmoded pay system, ineffective performance management, and low employee engagement. There have been calls for federal workers' pay to be aligned with private sector pay, but there are issues with the current model and methodology used to estimate pay gaps.

• The federal workforce has become more skilled and specialized, requiring advanced skills and degrees. Balancing the size and composition of the federal workforce to deliver high-quality services within budgetary realities is a key challenge. There have been efforts to make the federal compensation system more market-based and performance-oriented, but this is not an easy task.

• Improving human capital management is within the control of federal agencies, and they should make better use of existing tools and flexibilities. Agency leaders and managers should prioritize human capital and demonstrate sustained commitment to addressing these challenges.
</summary>

<summary>

* The USDA and FDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of different food products.
* The Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system is used to minimize the risk of contamination in food processing facilities.
* FDA and FSIS inspect food facilities to verify implementation of HACCP plans.
* Individual states also conduct yearly inspections of food-processing facilities.
* Following 9/11, the federal government increased efforts to address potential deliberate contamination of agriculture and food products.
* FDA and FSIS have used emergency funds to enhance the security of imported food and support food security activities.
* FDA and USDA have taken actions to better protect the food supply against deliberate contamination.
* The food safety statutes do not specifically authorize FDA or USDA to require food processors to implement security measures.
* FDA and USDA have issued voluntary security guidelines to the food-processing industry, but have not assessed the extent to which they are being implemented.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program, authorized in 1983, aims to enhance the counterterrorism skills of friendly countries, strengthen ties with friendly governments, and promote human rights.
- ATA offers training and equipment, focusing on critical capabilities like crisis management, cyberterrorism, and dignitary protection, emphasizing law enforcement and human rights.
- ATA is State's largest counterterrorism program, with funding increasing from $25 million in 2000 to $171 million in 2007, allocated mainly to the top 10 recipient countries.
- S/CT and DS/T/ATA, responsible for ATA's policy oversight and implementation, lack clear guidance on determining assistance priorities and ensuring support for broader U.S. policy goals.
- S/CT places countries in priority categories based on threats, diplomatic engagement, and other factors, but there is no systematic process for planning assistance based on needs assessments and program reviews.
- DS/T/ATA program managers for Kenya, Indonesia, Pakistan, and the Philippines did not consistently use ATA country needs assessments and program reviews for assistance decisions.
- ATA country-specific needs assessments and program reviews lack prioritization, specific timeframes, and clear links to capabilities, limiting their usefulness for targeting assistance.
- S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically use the assessments to create annual country assistance plans, relying instead on DS/T/ATA officials' knowledge and experience.
- State has not developed clear measures and a process for assessing sustainability, the extent to which assistance has enabled partner nations to achieve and maintain advanced counterterrorism capabilities.
</summary>

<summary>

- The MAS program is the largest interagency contracting vehicle, directed by GSA.
- Government buyers pay fees for using other agencies’ GWACs, MACs, and schedule contracts.
- Large departments are turning to enterprisewide contracts to acquire goods and services.
- In fiscal year 2008, $60 billion was spent on GWACs, MACs, the MAS program, and enterprisewide contracts.
- Sales under the MAS program have been relatively flat, and obligations under GWACs have declined slightly.
- The total number of MACs and enterprisewide contracts in use by agencies is unknown.
- Concerns about contract duplication and vendors offering similar products on many contracts exist.
- Limited governmentwide policy is in place for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
- GSA lacks reliable and comprehensive data to effectively leverage, manage, and oversee interagency contracts.
- GSA’s MAS program is still the primary governmentwide buying program for commercial goods and services.

</summary>

<summary>

- The federal government has spent billions of dollars on failed and troubled IT investments, leading to the formation of 18F and USDS to address the government's IT challenges.
- 18F, an office within GSA, provides a team of experts to help agencies rapidly deploy digital services and has guiding principles such as open source development, user-centered design, and agile software development.
- USDS, led by the Administrator and Deputy Federal CIO, aims to transform the most important digital services for citizens by recruiting private sector experts and partnering them with government agencies.
- Both 18F and USDS have faced challenges in establishing outcome-oriented goals, measuring performance, and prioritizing projects, making it difficult to hold the programs accountable for results.
- OMB has called for agencies to establish digital service teams, but USDS policy does not require agencies to define the expected responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital service teams, hindering the ability for CIOs to carry out their IT management responsibilities.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was extended until October 3, 2010, due to the severity of the financial crisis and the need to maintain resources for financial stability.
* The decision to extend TARP was made at the highest levels within the Treasury Department and involved considerable deliberation on the effectiveness of existing government actions and potential policy options.
* Treasury's decision to extend TARP was influenced by ongoing weaknesses in key areas of the economy, such as housing market indicators and financial conditions for small businesses.
* The extension of TARP allowed Treasury to reallocate existing commitments and make additional funds available for some programs, with new commitments limited to the Making Home Affordable Program (MHA) and small business lending programs through CBLI.
* The extension of TARP marked a shift in focus from capitalizing institutions and stabilizing securitization markets to mitigating preventable foreclosures and improving financial conditions for small banks and small businesses.
* Treasury estimated that new commitments under MHA and CBLI could increase the costs of TARP by $25 billion, but the program was expected to ultimately cost taxpayers $105.4 billion, significantly less than initially estimated.
* The decision to extend TARP was made in coordination with relevant policymakers and financial regulators, including the Federal Reserve and FDIC, to ensure a broader market context and minimize the cost to taxpayers.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) has an agreement with ARC, an office within Treasury’s Bureau of the Public Debt, for contracting support. ARC is a franchise fund that relies on revenue from federal agency customers to pay organizational expenses.

• OSC hired a consultant, Alan J. Hicks, on March 17, 2

<summary>

* The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) of 2014 aims to increase transparency in federal spending by expanding on previous legislation and requiring the disclosure of federal agency expenditures linked to specific programs.
* The act establishes new data standards for agency-reported award and financial information, with OMB and Treasury responsible for leading government-wide implementation and ensuring the accuracy, completeness, and consistency of federal spending data.
* Agencies have identified challenges in implementing the DATA Act, including reporting intragovernmental transactions and missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information, which may affect the quality of data posted on USASpending.gov.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) costs are mainly associated with military personnel and operation and maintenance accounts.
* Estimating the cost of ongoing military operations is difficult due to changing operational requirements, which can cause operations to cost more or less than originally estimated.
* DOD has several authorities to meet its needs if operations cost more than originally estimated, including transferring and reprogramming funds and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations.
* In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, the military services received about $52.4 billion and about $62.1 billion, respectively, in supplemental appropriations for GWOT military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses.
* However, DOD and the military services have lost visibility over GWOT funds provided through annual appropriations, making it difficult to know how much, if any, was used to support GWOT in those years.
* Program Budget Decision 736, approved in 2002, provided for increasing DOD's annual budget request by more than $10 billion per year plus inflation in fiscal years 2003 through 2007 to enhance the department's efforts to respond to terrorism.
* In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, the Army, Air Force, and Navy received additional funds in their annual appropriations, totaling about $7.9 billion, for support of military operations in the war on terrorism.
* However, DOD and the military services cannot be certain that these funds were actually used to support GWOT-related activities, as there is no specific information about which programs or activities received the funds or how they were eventually expended.
* DOD took steps to adjust the fiscal year 2005 request for supplemental appropriations to reflect the receipt of funds provided through Program Budget Decision 736.
* The difference between supplemental appropriations available to the military services for GWOT military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses compared to reported obligations varied by service in fiscal year 2004, requiring DOD and the military services to take several actions to cover the gaps.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel of visitors for business or tourism, providing visa-free travel to the United States for eligible countries.
* The program aims to boost international business and tourism, increase airline revenues, and create economic benefits for the United States, while also allowing the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to allocate more resources to visa-issuing posts in countries with higher risk applicant pools.
* To qualify for the VWP, countries must offer reciprocal visa-free travel privileges to U.S. citizens, have a low refusal rate for business and tourism visas, issue machine-readable passports, share information on lost or stolen passports, accept repatriation of nationals, and not compromise U.S. law enforcement or security interests.
* In 2008, DHS created the Visa Waiver Program Oversight Unit to oversee VWP activities and monitor participating countries' adherence to program requirements, and established an interagency working group to help fulfill its responsibilities.
* Since the 9/11 attacks, Congress has passed several laws to strengthen border security policies and procedures, including the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 and the 9/11 Act, which added security requirements for all VWP countries and increased the frequency of assessments of each country's continued participation in the program.
</summary>

<summary>

- GSA's Federal Technology Service, in conjunction with the IMC, is responsible for ensuring federal agencies have access to telecommunications services. They face challenges in finalizing the Networx acquisition program, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring and scheduling contracts, and initiating implementation planning for a smooth transition from current contracts.
- GSA has not yet established comprehensive performance measures for the Networx acquisition program, and the accuracy and completeness of telecommunications service inventories vary among agencies, making it unclear how to make properly informed acquisition planning decisions.

</summary>

<summary>
• Between 1984 and 1995, the foster care population in the United States grew from 276,000 to 494,000 children, with 261,000 of them supported by federal funds.
• The Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes and to provide services to families and children to reunite them.
• In response to prolonged stays of children in foster care, 26 states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing, with 23 states choosing a time frame of 12 months or less.
• States have implemented various operational and procedural changes to expedite and improve the permanency process, including low-cost, creative methods for financing and providing services that address specific barriers to reuniting families.
• Some states have experimented with concurrent planning, where child welfare officials work toward reuniting a family while developing an alternate plan for permanently removing the child if reunification efforts fail.
• The success of these initiatives depends on local leadership involvement, consensus building, and sustained resources, but they can also create unintended consequences, such as a lack of adoptive homes for children available for adoption.
• Many of these initiatives lack evaluations designed to assess their impact, making it difficult for program officials and policymakers to fully understand their overall impact.
</summary>

<summary>

* The baby boom generation, defined as those born between 1946 and 1964, will start turning 65 in 2011 and the last will turn 65 in 2029.
* This will lead to a rise in the aged dependency ratio, which is the ratio of the working age population (20-64) to the population aged 65 or older.
* The aged dependency ratio was 21% in 2000, but is projected to reach 35% by 2030, meaning there will be fewer than three working-age individuals for every person aged 65 or over.
* The increase in the aged dependency ratio is not only due to the growing numbers of older persons, but also the slowing growth of the labor force of younger workers.
* From 1950 to 1990, the labor force under 55 grew at an average annual rate of 1.9%, but from 1990 to 2000, the average annual growth rate for this group was 1.0%.
* The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) projects that from 2000 to 2025, labor force growth will slow to an annual rate of 0.3%.
* Several recent changes in Social Security retirement policy could strengthen incentives to work longer, including the elimination of the practice of reducing Social Security benefits when a beneficiary has earnings and has reached the normal retirement age.
* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) promotes the employment of older persons based upon their ability rather than age and prohibits age discrimination in employment.
* The federal government provides preferential tax treatment under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) for pension plans that meet certain requirements to encourage employers to establish and maintain pension plans for their employees.
* The number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades and they will become an increasingly significant proportion of all workers.
* In 2000, 18.4 million persons over age 55, or about one-third of the over-55 population, were in the labor force.
* BLS estimates that there will be 31.8 million older labor force participants in 2015,

<summary>

* The Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) is responsible for overseeing the Medicare program, which has two parts: hospital insurance (Part A) and supplementary medical insurance (Part B).
* In fiscal year 1997, HCFA served about 33 million beneficiaries and processed an estimated 900 million claims from hundreds of thousands of providers.
* HCFA is also responsible for paying and monitoring more than 400 managed care health plans that serve more than 5 million beneficiaries.
* The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) and the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) granted HCFA substantial authority and responsibility to reform Medicare.
* HCFA has slightly less than 4,000 full-time employees and oversees more than 60 claims processing contractors that are insurance companies.
* HCFA's workforce has been decreasing, with almost 40 percent of the organization turning over in the past 5 years, leading to a loss of experienced staff.
* Managers are concerned about the loss of experienced staff, as it makes it difficult to implement multiple new payment systems concurrently.
* HCFA is currently facing full agendas with tight deadlines, and the recent reorganization has added to the stresses associated with any organizational change.
* Managers are having difficulties establishing new communication and coordination links within units and across the agency due to the reorganization.
* HCFA's focus group participants emphasized that it will be difficult to replace its experienced staff in the short term, as new employees need extensive on-the-job training to replace lost expertise.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is responsible for promoting the health, welfare, and dignity of veterans through medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials. VA consists of three major components: Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and National Cemetery Administration (NCA), served by approximately 340,000 employees.

• VA's IT infrastructure is critical for delivering benefits and services, with approximately 240 information systems, 314,000 desktop computers, 30,000 laptops, and 460,000 network user accounts. VBA and VHA rely on IT systems for benefits determination, claims processing, patient admission, and health records access. However, some systems are outdated, such as PAID (53 years old) and BDN (51 years old), which VA plans to replace by 2017 and 2018, respectively.

• VA's 6-year strategic plan focuses on increasing veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminating the disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness. The department plans to improve access through technology, eliminate the backlog with an electronic claims process, and collaborate with other agencies to streamline data entry systems for housing and services. VA spent $3.9 billion on IT in FY2015, with $548 million on new systems development, $2.3 billion on maintaining existing systems, and $1 billion on payroll and administration.

• VA faces challenges in IT development, modernization, and interoperability with DOD. The department has engaged in efforts to expand interoperability between existing electronic health record systems, including mapping data to standards and expanding the functionality of the Joint Legacy Viewer. However, VA and DOD lack outcome-oriented goals and metrics for their interoperability efforts, making it difficult to determine the value and benefits of these efforts.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is primarily supported by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments.
* The Trust Fund provides funding for FAA's two capital accounts, the Airport Improvement Program (AIP) and the Facilities and Equipment (F&E) account, as well as the Research, Engineering, and Development (RE&D) account and part of FAA's Operations account.
* The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system from one based mainly on excise taxes to one based more on cost-based charges, with funding for ATO coming primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.
* The proposal would also create an advisory board and give FAA limited borrowing authority, and would establish two new budget accounts, Air Traffic Organization and Safety and Operations, to align with FAA's lines of business and proposed funding.
* The current funding structure, with some modifications to the excise taxes and tax rates and changes in the levels of General Fund contributions, has successfully funded a growing FAA budget, but FAA has expressed concern about the long-run revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency of its funding.
* Some of the administration's proposed changes for funding FAA, such as establishing direct user charges for commercial aviation and substantially increasing fuel taxes for general aviation, are intended to link FAA's revenues more closely with its costs.
* The effectiveness of the proposed funding structure in linking costs with revenues depends critically on how well FAA's new cost allocation method assigns costs to users and on how closely the proposed funding structure adheres to the principle of cost-based funding.
</summary>

<summary>

- The National Institutes of Health (NIH) made over 21,50

* The report examines federal initiatives supporting solar energy technologies in fiscal years 2010 and 201

<summary>

* The Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan focuses on development and construction, while in Iraq, the focus is on reconstruction.
* The number of CERP projects in Afghanistan costing more than $500,000 increased from 9 in fiscal year 2004 to 129 in fiscal year 2

<summary>

- DOD has developed new protective equipment like the JSLIST suit to address issues with older models, but there are still concerns about inventory management and interoperability across services.
- A 2001 report found that DOD inaccurately assessed the risk of wartime shortages of protective equipment, which could negatively impact readiness and acquisition decisions.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has authority to authorize all unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) operations in the national airspace, but currently only allows access on a case-by-case basis through Certificates of Waiver or Authorization, Special Airworthiness Certificates, and Section 333 exemptions.
• FAA has been planning for further UAS integration through the UAS Comprehensive Plan and Roadmap, which outline overarching goals, strategic objectives, and a phased approach to integration, and has issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for the operations of small UASs.
</summary>

• The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is responsible for implementing safeguards to prevent the diversion of nuclear material to weapons in countries that have signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT).
• IAEA's safeguards measures include inspections, material-accounting measures, containment measures, and surveillance devices. However, IAEA's ability to detect undeclared activities remains largely untested, and the agency faces limitations in its inspection rights and access to information.

<summary>

• The Rehabilitation Act defines a person with a disability as someone who has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities. Federal efforts are in place to promote the employment of individuals with disabilities in the federal workforce, including special hiring authorities like Schedule A and appointments for veterans with disabilities. To qualify for a Schedule A appointment, an applicant must provide proof of disability and a certification of job readiness.

• Executive Order 13548 requires federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities, designate a senior-level official to oversee these efforts, and track the number of individuals with disabilities in the workforce using OPM’s Standard Form 256, Self-Disclosure of Disability (SF-256). The executive order also aims to improve return-to-work outcomes for employees who sustain work-related injuries and illnesses through initiatives like the Protecting Our Workers and Ensuring Reemployment (POWER) Initiative.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) oversees two disability programs: Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI). Both programs use the same definition of disability, but have different purposes and requirements for entitlement.
• DI, established in 1956, provides insurance for workers who become disabled and is financed through payroll taxes. SSI, established in 1972, ensures a standard minimum income for individuals with disabilities and limited income and resources.
• Work incentive provisions exist in both programs to encourage beneficiaries to return to work, but the provisions differ in terms of safeguards for continuing eligibility, income, and medical coverage.
• Approximately 1.2 million individuals receive benefits from both DI and SSI, with over half having a mental impairment. These concurrent beneficiaries are likely to be female, average age 45, and have low earnings from work.
• SSA field offices, which handle most interactions with concurrent beneficiaries, use specialized or generalist employees for DI and SSI programs. However, there is little coordination between the programs, making it difficult to serve concurrent beneficiaries effectively.
• SSA has taken steps to improve service for concurrent beneficiaries, such as creating a new position and software for work-related issues, but these initiatives are still being tested and evaluated.
• SSA guidance for administering the DI and SSI programs is contained in a voluminous document, making it challenging for specialists to use when collecting work activity information for concurrent beneficiaries.

</summary>

• The Federal Student Aid (FSA) is a Performance-Based Organization (PBO) established in 1998 to manage and administer student financial assistance programs under the Higher Education Act of 1965.
• FSA's programs provide more than $50 billion in aid to around 8 million students and their families annually, involving about 5,300 schools, 4,100 lenders, and 36 guaranty agencies.
• FSA's enabling legislation requires the appointment of a Chief Operating Officer (COO), development of 5-year and annual performance plans, performance agreements for the COO and senior managers, and a student loan ombudsman.
• FSA's performance plan discusses three strategic goals: increasing customer and employee satisfaction while decreasing unit cost. However, the plan could be more useful for congressional decision-makers regarding systems integration and program integrity.
• FSA has taken steps towards developing a strategic direction, but additional actions are needed. FSA's performance plan includes measures for gauging progress in meeting strategic goals, and FSA uses the American Customer Satisfaction Index and Gallup Q12 to measure customer and employee satisfaction.
• FSA's calculation of unit cost has limitations, making it less useful for congressional decision-makers. The calculation does not measure total program costs, and comparing unit cost across years is difficult due to changes in the method of calculation.
• FSA's performance plan has limitations in addressing systems integration and program integrity. It is not always clear how the goals and strategies included in the plan relate to systems integration, and the plan provides limited information on strategies for achieving program integrity.

<summary>

* Program evaluations are studies that assess program performance and can provide valuable information for program planning, management, and oversight.
* In a 2013 survey, most federal managers reported lacking recent evaluations of their programs, but those who had evaluations found them helpful for understanding program performance, assessing effectiveness, and making improvements.
* A 2014 survey of PIOs found uneven levels of evaluation expertise, organizational support, and use across the government, with agencies with centralized leadership reporting greater evaluation coverage and use.
* GPRAMA, a law established in 2014, requires agencies to establish priority goals and report on their progress, and charges the Performance Improvement Council with facilitating the exchange of successful practices.
* OMB has issued several memorandums since 2009 encouraging the use of rigorous impact evaluation and evidence-based decision making in the federal government.
* The Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2016 and the Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 encourage federal agency evaluation and the use of evidence in decision making.
* A 2017 survey found no change government-wide in managers' access to evaluations since 2013, with about 40% of managers reporting having access to recent evaluations of their programs.
* Managers with evaluations reported that they contributed to a great or very great extent to assessing program effectiveness or implementing changes to improve program management or performance.
* Factors that facilitate evaluation use include leadership support, a strong body of evidence, engaging stakeholders, and an enabling environment with resources and transparent evaluation results.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Social Security Administration (SSA) has been sending Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statements (PEBES) to workers since 1995, providing them with estimates of their retirement benefits.
* Fewer than 2% of workers request these statements annually, but the PEBES legislation requires SSA to send them to eligible workers who have not requested a statement.
* SSA's goals for issuing PEBES include informing the public about benefits, assisting workers in planning for their financial future, and ensuring accurate earnings records.
* The projected cost of $80 million in fiscal year 2000 includes production and personnel costs, with 608 staff-years required to handle the PEBES workload.
* SSA's approach for estimating future retirement benefits is considered reasonable, but it does not account for special circumstances that could affect individual benefits.
* The PEBES estimates may overstate or understate benefits for certain individuals, such as federal workers eligible for both Civil Service Retirement System and Social Security benefits.
* SSA has conducted surveys and focus groups to assess public reactions to the PEBES, resulting in revisions to the statement, such as adding an estimate for retirement at age 62.
* Overall public reaction to receiving an unsolicited PEBES has been favorable, with most respondents indicating they were glad to receive the statement and found the information helpful.
* However, the current statement still provides too much information, overwhelming readers and presenting information in a way that undermines its usefulness.
* SSA officials have acknowledged these weaknesses and revised the Commissioner's message for the 1997 PEBES, but concerns remain about the statement's complexity and the public's understanding of the information provided.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing the Automated Land and Mineral Records System (ALMRS) to manage and automate land and mineral records and case processing activities. The ALMRS project has an estimated life-cycle cost of $403 million and is expected to provide an efficient means to record, maintain, and retrieve land description, ownership, and use information.

• The ALMRS project consists of three components: ALMRS Initial Operating Capability (IOC), Geographic Coordinate Data Base (GCDB), and technology modernization and rehost of selected systems. The ALMRS IOC component will provide support for case processing activities and information for land and resource management activities. The GCDB component will contain geographic coordinates and survey information for land parcels, and other databases will be integrated with GCDB. The technology modernization component involves installing computer and telecommunications equipment and converting selected management and administrative systems to a relational database system.

• As of April 30, 1995, about $262.8 million had been obligated for ALMRS/Modernization, and BLM plans to install about 730 more workstations and other equipment in fiscal year 1995. However, initial hardware installation for Alaska and Wyoming state and subordinate offices has been delayed because of a shortage of hardware funds. The collection and validation of land and mineral data for ALMRS IOC are on schedule, and the development of ALMRS IOC software is currently on schedule.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Information Quality Act (IQA) of 2001 consists of two major elements: the development of guidelines for ensuring and maximizing the quality of information disseminated by federal agencies and the establishment of administrative mechanisms allowing affected persons to seek correction of information maintained and disseminated by the agencies.
* The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) were responsible for developing the governmentwide IQA guidelines and assisting agencies in meeting the act's requirements.
* Agencies were required to develop their own guidelines, which were to include administrative mechanisms for correction requests from affected parties, and report to the OMB about the number and nature of IQA complaints and their handling of such complaints.
* The implementation of IQA was considered a continuation of previous federal efforts to improve the quality of information, and it required agencies to manage their information resources to improve the integrity, quality, and utility of information for all users.
* However, the implementation of IQA faced challenges, such as the lack of IQA information on some independent agencies' websites and the difficulty in locating IQA information on some agencies' websites.
</summary>

<summary>

* In August 2005, Hurricane Katrina caused significant damage and human casualties in the Gulf Coast region.
* The Stafford Act authorizes the federal government to provide assistance for saving lives, reducing suffering, mitigating lost income effects, and repairing or rebuilding certain damaged facilities.
* As of June 2006, nearly $88 billion was appropriated by the Congress for relief and recovery efforts related to recent Gulf Coast hurricanes.

* The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) uses appropriations made to the Stafford Act's Disaster Relief Fund to assist relief and recovery efforts.
* Initially, $62.3 billion was appropriated for the response and recovery effort related to Hurricane Katrina, with FEMA receiving $60 billion for the Disaster Relief Fund.
* As of late December 2005, FEMA had obligated about 42% of the $60 billion it received, and additional funds were provided through subsequent emergency supplemental appropriation acts.

* FEMA can issue mission assignments to other federal agencies for tasks such as search and rescue missions or debris removal.
* Mission assignments provide the recipient agency with reimbursable budgetary authority, and agencies bill FEMA for the work performed, which FEMA reimburses using the Intra-Governmental Payment and Collection (IPAC) system.
* The federal government is not adequately tracking and reporting on the use of the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided to 23 federal agencies.

* FEMA does not have mechanisms in place to collect and report on information from other agencies that are performing work on its behalf through mission assignments.

* FTA considers factors related to TOD potential when assessing proposed projects, but these factors make up only a small percentage of all factors considered.
* The benefits of TOD can be driven by both transit-oriented and more auto-oriented uses, and there are inherent limitations in evaluating some factors that support or hinder TOD.

* The Refugee Act of 1980 provides a procedure for admitting refugees to the United States and maintains provisions to resettle refugees quickly and encourage self-sufficiency.
* Nine national voluntary agencies, with a network of about 350 affiliates, determine where refugees will live in the United States with approval from the Department of State.

- * Both mutual funds and banks act as financial intermediaries, but mutual funds primarily invest in securities while banks make loans or invest in debt securities.
- * The importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining, with companies increasingly turning to securities markets for their financial needs.
- * Securitization, where banks provide initial financing for loans that are then sold as securities, has also contributed to the decline in bank loans' importance.
- * The growth of mutual funds has had a significant impact on bank deposits, with sizable amounts of money being attracted to mutual funds that might have otherwise been placed in deposits.
- * The total net flows into mutual funds from all sources from 1990 to 1994 were $1,067 billion, and the impact on deposits may have been sizable but probably less than $700 billion.
- * The shift of funds from deposits to mutual funds has not affected the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.
- * However, the movement of funds from deposits to mutual funds has shifted the intermediaries through which finance flows, with mutual funds becoming a greater source of new finance to the economy than bank lending.
- * The availability of finance for different borrower sectors could be disproportionally affected by this movement, but it is difficult to measure the extent of this impact from statistical information.

* The Year 2000 computing crisis poses a high risk of severely disrupting critical services provided by the government and private sector, affecting financial transactions, flights, power, and national defense.
* The problem is particularly acute in America's interconnected infrastructure, where a single failure could have adverse repercussions across key economic sectors, including information and telecommunications, banking and finance, health and safety services, transportation, power and water, and manufacturing and small business.
* The information and telecommunications sector is especially important, as reliable services are essential to nearly every public and private organization. However, there are indications of Year 2000 readiness problems in the international arena, with only 14% of countries surveyed by the World Bank having a national program.
* The Gartner Group's survey found that the United States, Canada, the Netherlands, Belgium, Australia, and Sweden were Year 2000 leaders, while nations including Germany, India, Japan, and Russia were behind. The survey also found that 23% of all companies had not started a Year 2000 effort.
* Major disruptions could occur if the Year 2000 problem is not corrected, including grounded or delayed flights, degraded safety, customer inconvenience, increased airline costs, grounded military equipment, shortages of vital items for military operations, and problems with medical devices and scientific laboratory equipment.
* The federal government faces a tremendous challenge in addressing the Year 2000 problem, as many of its computer systems were designed and developed 20 to 25 years ago, are poorly documented, and use obsolete computer languages. The government also depends on the telecommunications infrastructure and embedded computer systems in facilities to deliver services.
* Overall, the government's 24 major departments and agencies are making slow progress in fixing their systems, with only 40% of mission-critical systems compliant as of May 1998. Some agencies are significantly behind schedule, and many have not adequately acted to establish priorities, solidify data exchange agreements, or develop contingency plans.

- The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to provide flood insurance and reduce federal costs for repairing flood damage.
* FEMA is responsible for managing NFIP, which offers subsidized and full-risk premiums based on flood zone designations.
* NFIP has mapped flood risks and currently participates in over 20,000 communities, but the number of repetitive loss properties and policies with subsidized premium rates have increased.
* Congress has enacted legislation to strengthen NFIP, including mandatory purchase requirements and grant programs for property mitigation.
* NFIP's financial challenges include premium rates not fully reflecting actual risks, limited borrowing authority, and a lack of reinsurance for catastrophic losses.
* Increasing premium rates to fully reflect the risk of loss could result in more accurate premium rates, decreased costs for taxpayers, and increased private market participation.
* However, eliminating subsidized and grandfathered rates would increase costs for some homeowners and potentially reduce participation in NFIP.
* A catastrophic loss fund within NFIP could help pay for losses, but steep increases in premiums could reduce participation and increase taxpayer costs.
* A variety of actions could be taken to mitigate these disadvantages, such as phasing out subsidized rates over time or offering targeted assistance to those in need.
</summary>

• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was enacted to address concerns about inadequate oversight and accountability of federal assistance provided to state and local governments. The act required a single audit for state and local governments receiving at least $100,000 in federal financial assistance, aiming to replace multiple grant audits with one audit of an entity as a whole.

• The Single Audit Act Amendments of 1996 refined the Single Audit Act of 1984, establishing uniform requirements for all federal grant recipients, including nonprofit organizations, hospitals, and universities. The amendments aimed to ensure a more cost-beneficial threshold for requiring single audits, focus audit work on programs that present the greatest financial risk to the federal government, provide for timely reporting of audit results, and promote better analyses of audit results.

• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.
• TVA's operations and power program are financed through revenue from electricity sales and borrowing, with a debt ceiling set by Congress at $30 billion.
• TVA's retirement system is administered by a Board of Directors and is not subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
• TVA's strategic plan outlines its goal to reduce debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023.
• TVA uses a 10-year long-range financial plan to determine the amount of funds available for capital investment.
• TVA has experienced less than anticipated electricity demand growth over the past 20 years and now forecasts little, if any, growth in demand.
• TVA's financial condition worsened in the late 1960s and 1970s due to construction delays, cost overruns, and operational shutdowns in its nuclear program.
• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities affect its financial health and operations, and no mechanism is in place to ensure the pension plan is fully funded.
• GPRAMA requires TVA to report major management challenges and performance information, but TVA is not fully meeting this requirement.

* In the late 1970s, First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc. became a major lender to the energy industry in the Southwest United States.

* In 1988, First City entered into a recapitalization agreement with the FDIC, which included a $970 million capital infusion and the creation of a "collecting bank" to dispose of certain troubled assets.
* However, despite the recapitalization, First City's banks continued to engage in high-risk lending practices and experienced further losses, leading to their failure in 1992.
* The FDIC estimated that the sale of the failed banks would result in a surplus of about $60 million, but this was later revised to over $200 million.
* The holding company for First City Bancorporation filed lawsuits alleging that the regulators had acted illegally and unnecessarily closed a solvent banking organization.

* ICE's Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC) is responsible for the 287(g) program, which is part of the ACCESS program offering various assistance programs to state and local law enforcement agencies.
* The 287(g) program has three models for state and local law enforcement participation: jail model, task force model, and joint model, with each having different functions and responsibilities.
* The 287(g) program has rapidly grown in recent years, with DHS appropriations acts providing funds specifically for the program and accompanying committee reports providing guidance on program implementation.
* Participating state and local law enforcement agencies may apply for financial assistance to cover some costs associated with the program, either directly from ICE or through grants provided by the DOJ.
* The 287(g) program lacks several management controls, such as documented program objectives, specific program-related documents, defined program information to be tracked, and performance measures to assess effectiveness.
* ICE senior program officials stated that the main objective of the 287(g) program is to enhance community safety by addressing serious criminal activity committed by removable aliens, but this objective is not clearly documented or communicated in program-related materials.

* The Bureau is recommended to provide comprehensive information backed by supporting documentation in its future funding requests for planning and development activities.

• The Medicare program, since its inception in 1966, has relied on health insurers to process and pay claims, as a way to win acceptance from providers who feared government control over healthcare.
• The current system of using health insurers for claims administration has been maintained due to subsequent regulations and practices, but the number of such companies willing to serve as Medicare contractors has declined.
• The need to broaden the pool of entities allowed to be contractors has increased due to the decline in the number of contractors since 1980 and the potential of new types of business entities for administering Medicare's claims processing and related functions.
• The Social Security Act allows Medicare to deviate from the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) regarding contracting, including the lack of full and open competition for intermediary or carrier contracts.
• Medicare could benefit from various contracting reforms, such as directly choosing contractors on a competitive basis, allowing contractors to specialize in specific functions, paying contractors based on performance, and terminating contracts more efficiently.
• The agency has submitted legislative proposals since 1993 to repeal the provider nomination authority and allow contracting with entities other than health insurers, but these have not been successful.
• Functional contracting, which involves hiring entities for specific claims administration activities, could further improve program management by enabling CMS to select contractors more skilled at certain tasks.
• Allowing Medicare to offer financial incentives to contractors for high-quality performance and terminating contracts more efficiently may promote better program management.
• Implementing performance-based contracting and terminating contractors more efficiently will not be without significant challenges, and careful planning and time would be needed to ensure effective promotion of better performance and accountability.

</summary>

• Social Security benefits are calculated using a common formula and are financed through payroll taxes, with receipts deposited into the OASI and DI trust funds. Beneficiaries can receive multiple types of benefits over their lifetimes, and the programs are tightly linked in terms of financing and eligibility.

• Between 1993 and 1996, the federal civilian workforce was reduced by about 12 percent, with certain agencies experiencing larger cuts, such as HUD (14%), DOI (13%), GSA (22%), NASA (13%), and OPM (42%).
• The Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 and the National Performance Review drove these reductions, aiming to streamline operations, reduce management control positions, and improve government operations through reinvention and quality management techniques.
• Agencies were required to measure their performance under the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993, which included developing strategic plans, annual performance plans, and reports on program performance.
• Over 70 federal organizations participated in pilot projects for performance planning and reporting, including GSA, HUD, and OPM.
• Selected components within HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM were examined to determine the extent of downsizing, with HUD's Office of Housing, DOI's Bureau of Reclamation, GSA's Public Buildings Service, NASA's Human Space Flight Program, and OPM's Investigations Service experiencing significant reductions.
• Actions taken to maintain performance during downsizing included refocusing missions, reengineering work processes, and building and maintaining employee skills.
• Examples of these actions include HUD's shift from water project construction to water resources management, GSA's implementation of the "Can't Beat GSA Leasing" and "Can't Beat GSA Space Alterations" programs, and NASA's focus on research and development.
• Components also took steps to ensure skilled workforces, such as retraining employees and consolidating expertise in fewer locations.
• Despite concerns about workforce sufficiency and skill retention, officials from the five components generally believed that efforts to maintain performance had been successful, and customers remained satisfied.

</summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) has been looking for ways to increase investments in modernization without raising the overall defense budgets, focusing on reducing support operation costs and infrastructure.
• The Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) requested the Defense Science Board (DSB) to identify DOD activities that could be done more efficiently by the private sector and to estimate the expected savings from outsourcing.
• The DSB's first report, released in 1996, focused on outsourcing and privatization issues, concluding that DOD could save 30-40% of logistics costs by outsourcing support services. The second report, with a broader scope, recommended that DOD only handle warfighting, direct battlefield support, policy-making, and oversight activities, outsourcing all other activities.
• The DSB estimated that an aggressive DOD outsourcing initiative could generate savings of $7-12 billion annually by fiscal year 2002, with $6 billion coming from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities, primarily through outsourcing support functions.
• However, Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) analyzed the DSB's savings estimates and found that the $6 billion savings from logistics infrastructure activities were overstated by about $1 billion and that another $3 billion in projected savings would be difficult to achieve or unlikely to be achieved.
• The DSB's savings estimate was overstated due to understated contract administration and oversight costs, claimed steady-state savings from one-time inventory savings, and unachievable savings assumptions.
• The DSB's estimate of $1.5 billion in annual savings from equipment reliability improvements is also overstated by at least $1.2 billion, based on a Logistics Management Institute study.
• DOD has found that infrastructure reductions, whether through outsourcing or other means, are difficult due to up-front investments, installation closures, and job eliminations.
• Despite the problems with DSB's estimates, DOD is encouraged to move forward with a realistic and achievable cost-reduction program, including developing a detailed implementation plan for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of DOD’s logistics infrastructure.
</summary>

• The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act aim to protect the privacy and security of protected health information (PHI).
• HIPAA established the Privacy Rule, which governs the use and disclosure of PHI, and the Security Rule, which sets standards for the protection of electronic PHI.
• The HITECH Act expanded HIPAA's enforcement provisions and breach notification requirements, and it also promoted the adoption of health information technology.
• The Office for Civil Rights (OCR) is responsible for enforcing HIPAA and the HITECH Act, and it has developed an enforcement process that includes investigating complaints and conducting compliance reviews.
• From 2006 to 2010, OCR received an average of 8,000 Privacy and Security Rule complaints each year and conducted investigations in 66% of the cases, resulting in corrective actions.
• OCR has the authority to impose civil money penalties for failure to comply with the Privacy Rule, Security Rule, and Breach Notification Rule.
• In June 2011, OCR initiated efforts to conduct pilot audits of 150 covered entities by the end of December 2012, but it has not yet established plans for continuing the audit program or auditing business associates.
• The department has not yet issued required implementation guidance to assist entities in de-identifying PHI, and without a plan for deploying a sustained audit capability, OCR will lack the ability to ensure that covered entities and business associates are complying with HIPAA regulations.

• The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (EESA) was enacted in October 2008 to address the financial crisis and its impact on the global economy.
• Under EESA, the Treasury established various Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) programs, including the Capital Purchase Program (CPP), Public-Private Investment Program (PPIP), and Making Home Affordable (MHA) program.
• As of September 2014, Treasury had recovered all debt and equity investments made in PPIP, and many programs, such as the AIG Assistance Program and Capital Assessment Program, were no longer active.
• However, Treasury still holds investments in CPP, CDCI, and AIFP, and the housing assistance programs, including MHA, remain active.
• MHA includes several housing programs, with the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) being the cornerstone, aimed at reducing monthly payments for homeowners facing financial distress.
• The number of new HAMP permanent modifications has declined in recent years, but Treasury has taken steps to increase HAMP participation, such as extending the program application deadline and launching public service advertisements to raise awareness.

• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting enterprises that provide common administrative services, including contracting, to federal agencies.
• DOD primarily uses two franchise funds, GovWorks and FedSource, for contracting services, which are required to recover their full costs and are allowed to retain up to 4% of their total annual income.
• GovWorks and FedSource did not always follow competitive procedures, ensure fair and reasonable prices, or seek to negotiate or analyze prices, potentially missing opportunities for millions of dollars in savings for DOD.
• DOD customers may choose franchise funds for convenience and quick service, but DOD lacks a clear mechanism for determining whether using franchise funds' contracting services is in its best interest.

• The MHSS, which spends over $15 billion a year, is primarily responsible for medical readiness of active-duty military personnel, including providing medical support in preparation for and during combat and maintaining the health of the active-duty force during peacetime.
• Psychiatrists and clinical psychologists play a crucial role in meeting the MHSS medical readiness mission by providing mental health care that helps military active-duty personnel perform their duties before, during, and after combat or military operations.
• The MHSS created the PDP to increase the scope of practice of clinical psychologists in the military so they could treat their patients with psychotropic medication when needed, in response to a conference report dated September 28, 1988.
• The PDP is a 2-year training model that includes course work at the Uniformed Services University for the Health Sciences (USUHS) and clinical experience at Walter Reed Army Medical Center or the Malcolm Grow Medical Center.
• The first psychologists who completed the PDP faced delays of up to 14 months in getting prescribing privileges at the facilities where they were assigned, but recent graduates have received privileges within 2 months.
• The MHSS has not decided who should supervise prescribing psychologists, and all PDP graduates continue to practice under the supervision of a psychiatrist.
• The total cost of the PDP will be about $6.1 million through the completion of the proctored year for those currently in the program, or about $610,000 per psychologist who completes the program.
• The PDP has demonstrated that training psychologists to prescribe drugs can reduce psychiatrists' workloads, but the cost-effectiveness of this effort is unclear and depends on various factors, including the proportion of time prescribing psychologists would have to perform functions that psychiatrists would normally perform and the extent to which having psychologists prescribe medication would result in fewer psychiatrists in the MHSS.
